newsitem.title: UK: Zambian mine sees big loss unless trading improves.
newsitem.headline: Zambian mine sees big loss unless trading improves.

text.p: Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines, the jewel in the Zambian state's asset crown, warned on Thursday it would incur "a substantial loss" this financial year unless trading conditions improved dramatically in February and March.

In a statement released in London, chairman Luke Mwananshiku blamed falls in the prices of copper and cobalt, production difficulties at the group's smelters and a deferment by the company of a planned "retrenchment programme" because ZCCM could not pay for associated redundancy payments.
"I believe the recent increases in ZCCM's share price do not reflect the company's real situation," Mwananshiku stated.

ZCCM, which saw a production peak of 700,000 tonnes in the 1970s fall to around 310,000 tonnes in 1995/96, started last month on the road to a privatisation which is seen as crucial to the survival of Zambia's mining industry.

But Mwananshiku said the group, which made a loss of around $7.0 million in 1995/96, faced a very difficult six months in the run-up to its sell-off. "I do not expect shareholders to receive any proceeds from the privatisation," he reiterated.

"The company is currently operating at a loss and whilst the forthcoming privatisation is good news for ZCCM, shareholders should not forget that the company is burdened with over $800 million of debt and other liabilities, much of it short term."
The sell-off of ZCCM, the biggest state-owned company, began last month with the $28 million sale of an 80 percent stake in the Kansanshi copper mine.
Mwananshiku said he had warned at the time of that sale that investors were unlikely to receive any money from privatisation.
The government holds a 60 percent stake in the company, Anglo American Corp of South Africa a 27 percent stake with private investors holding the balance.
ZCCM, whose stock is quoted on the Paris stock exchange, saw its shares close 5.26 percent lower at 19.80 francs on Thursday.
